Sure, here is a precise problem for the student to solve:

What is the change in enthalpy (ΔH) for the combustion of methane gas (CH4) at standard conditions (298 K and 1 atm pressure) given the balanced chemical equation:

CH4(g) + 2O2(g) -> CO2(g) + 2H2O(g)

And the following data for the standard enthalpies of formation (ΔHf°) at 298 K:
ΔHf°[CH4(g)] = -74.8 kJ/mol
ΔHf°[CO2(g)] = -393.5 kJ/mol
ΔHf°[H2O(g)] = -241.8 kJ/mol
message_2:
To calculate the change in enthalpy (ΔH) for the combustion of methane gas (CH4) at standard conditions, we can use the following formula:

ΔH = Σ ΔHf°(products) - Σ ΔHf°(reactants)

For the given balanced chemical equation:

CH4(g) + 2O2(g) -> CO2(g) + 2H2O(g)

The standard enthalpies of formation (ΔHf°) at 298 K are:

ΔHf°[CH4(g)] = -74.8 kJ/mol
ΔHf°[CO2(g)] = -393.5 kJ/mol
ΔHf°[H2O(g)] = -241.8 kJ/mol

Now, we can plug these values into the formula:

ΔH = [1 × (-393.5 kJ/mol) + 2 × (-241.8 kJ/mol)] - [1 × (-74.8 kJ/mol) + 2 × 0 kJ/mol]

Note that the enthalpy of formation for O2(g) is 0 kJ/mol since it is in its standard state.

ΔH = (-393.5 - 2 × 241.8 + 74.8) kJ/mol
ΔH = (-393.5 - 483.6 + 74.8) kJ/mol
ΔH = (-802.3 + 74.8) kJ/mol
ΔH = -727.5 kJ/mol

So, the change in enthalpy (ΔH) for the combustion of methane gas (CH4) at standard conditions is -727.5 kJ/mol.
